awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Making Science Visible: Using Visualization Technology to Support Linguistically Diverse Middle School Students' Learning in Physical and Life Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
The growing diversity in public schools requires science educators to address the specific needs of English language learners (ELLs), students who speak a language other than English at home. Although ELLs are the fastest-growing demographic group in classrooms, many are historically underserved in mainstream science classrooms, particularly those from underrepresented minority groups. The significant increase of ELLs at public schools poses a challenge to science teachers in linguistically diverse classrooms as they try to support and engage all students in learning science. The proposed project will respond to this urgent need by investigating the potential benefits of interactive, dynamic visualization technologies, including simulations, animations, and visual models, in supporting science learning for all middle school students, including ELLs. This project will also identify design principles for developing such technology, develop additional ways to support student learning, and provide new guidelines for effective science teachers' professional development that can assist them to better serve students from diverse language backgrounds. The project has the potential to transform traditional science instruction for all students, including underserved ELLs, and to broaden their participation in science. 

In collaboration with eighth grade science teachers from two low-income middle schools in North Carolina, the project will focus on three objectives: (1) develop, test, and refine four open-source, web-based inquiry units featuring dynamic visualizations on energy and matter concepts in physical and life sciences, aligned with the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS); (2) investigate how dynamic visualizations can engage eighth-grade ELLs and native-English-speaking students in science practices and improve their understanding of energy and matter concepts; and (3) investigate which scaffolding approaches can help maximize ELLs' learning with visualizations. Research questions include: (1) Which kinds of dynamic visualizations (simulations, animations, visual models) lead to the best learning outcomes for all students within the four instructional science units?; (2) Do ELLs  benefit more from visualizations (or particular kinds of visualizations) than do native-English-speaking students?; and (3) What kinds of additional scaffolding activities (e.g., critiquing arguments vs. generating arguments) are needed by ELLs in order to achieve the greatest benefit? The project will use design-based research and mixed-methods approaches to accomplish its research objectives and address these questions. Furthermore, it will help science teachers develop effective strategies to support students' learning with visualizations. Products from this project, including four NGSS-aligned web-based inquiry units, the visualizations created for the project, professional development materials, and scaffolding approaches for teachers to use with ELLs, will be freely available through a project website and multiple professional development networks. The PI will collaborate with an advisory board of experts to develop the four instructional units, visualizations, and scaffolds, as well as with the participating teachers to refine these materials in an iterative fashion.  Evaluation of the materials and workshops will be provided each year by the advisory board members, and their feedback will be used to improve design and implementation for the next year.  The advisory board will also provide summative evaluation of student learning outcomes and will assess the success of the teachers' professional development workshops.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated (1) how interactive dynamic visualizations improved science learning for all students, including Multilingual Learners (MLs), in linguistically diverse classrooms, and (2) which design features and scaffolding approaches were most beneficial for MLs. The project focused on MLs who mainly or only speak a language other than English at home. In collaboration with eighth-grade science teachers from four Title I middle schools, we engaged in iterative design cycles to develop, implement, and revise four web-based inquiry units in physical science and life science. Each unit focused on a focal phenomenon personally relevant to our students, supported by three types of interactive dynamic visualizations (e.g., animations, simulations, and modeling tools). The visualizations were carefully designed to support MLs in making sense of unobservable scientific phenomena (e.g., energy and matter) through science practices emphasized in the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). They also provided various scaffolding features, such as automated feedback, molecular animations, interactive graphs, and prediction-reflection questions.

Throughout the project, both MLs and non-MLs consistently demonstrated significant learning gains from individual pre- to post-assessments. All students, including MLs, developed a more sophisticated understanding of the focal phenomena by integrating several disciplinary ideas in both written explanations and visual representations. Analyses of video data from linguistically diverse pairs showed that using different forms of visualizations created discourse-rich opportunities for MLs to share their interpretations of multiple resources and engage in arguments with their partners through science practices.

The results from several design studies revealed that multimodal adaptive feedback in modeling tools had a significantly positive impact on MLs. Such feedback provided MLs with customized support by addressing the specific ideas in their submitted models. We found that feedback was particularly helpful when it prompted MLs to distinguish among ideas using visual resources, compared to providing specific explanations about the target concepts. The findings from video data showed that this type of feedback encouraged MLs to compare their initial ideas to visual resources and to evaluate each other?s ideas to ensure successful revisions.

Through various professional development (PD) activities, the project also enhanced science teachers? understanding of the benefits of visualizations for MLs and helped them develop instructional strategies to implement visualizations in linguistically diverse classrooms. The project materials and findings were disseminated widely through presentations at national and international conferences, peer-reviewed publications, invited lectures, district-level PD, and the project website. The project also integrated research into education by offering several graduate and undergraduate students across disciplines, particularly those from underrepresented groups in STEM (e.g., women in Computer Science), opportunities to design visualizations for MLs and to engage in research activities.

The project directly benefitted 12 science teachers and their eighth-grade students across four Title I middle schools in North Carolina. Given that the design of our materials focused on MLs, the project has the potential to make a positive and lasting impact on science teaching and learning by providing linguistically diverse students with equitable learning opportunities to engage in language-intensive science practices. Moreover, the findings of this project can inform the design and development of new technology-enhanced learning environments and effective adaptive feedback for MLs. To better support science teachers, we developed additional teaching resources, including overviews of each unit and its alignment with standards and step-by-step guides on how to use each visualization. These materials can be valuable teaching resources for a broader group of science teachers and educators who serve large numbers of MLs, especially those at under-resourced schools.
